                           CORAM:
                           HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE REKHA PALLI
                           REKHA PALLI, J
                                               JUDGMENT

1. The present petition preferred under Article 226 of the Constitution of India seeks quashing and setting aside of an order dated 29.04.2021 passed by the respondent cancelling its contract with the petitioner and debarring it from participating in any of its tenders for a period of two years.

2. The petitioner - Johnson & Johnson Private Limited claims to be the Indian arm of the Johnson & Johnson USA, a multinational corporation that Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 1 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 develops medical devices, pharmaceutical products, and consumer packaged goods. The respondent is the All India Institute of Medical Sciences, New Delhi, an autonomous medical university and healthcare centre located in New Delhi, established under the All India Institute of Medical Sciences Act, 1956. It is the case of the petitioner that even though it has been collaborating with the respondent for the last several decades for supply of various medical devices without any complaint, the respondent passed the impugned order against the petitioner by holding it guilty of 'corrupt and fraudulent practices' on account of an erroneous presumption that the petitioner had deliberately misrepresented facts to influence the tender procurement process.

3. On 27.09.2019, the respondent, for the benefit of its Surgical Block (hereinafter referred to as 'AIIMS, SB'), issued a Tender Enquiry Document bearing Reference No. 03/SB/M&E/2019-20/St. (hereinafter referred to as 'TED') inviting bids for providing endo surgery equipment, namely, 12 Combined Single Generators for Ultrasonic Cutting and Coagulation device with advanced Radio-Frequency (RF) Energy technology, along with an equivalent number of accessories and consumables (collectively referred to as 'equipment'). These bids were invited online in a two-bid system, comprising of techno-commercial and financial bid components. Pursuant thereto, the petitioner submitted its bid on 15.11.2019 and, while the same was pending consideration with the respondent, a bid it had submitted on 14.09.2018 for supply of the same type of generator with different quantities of capital, accessories and consumables - sought under an earlier tender floated by the National Cancer Institute, Jhajjar (hereinafter referred to as 'the NCI') on 10.08.2018 - came to be accepted. The petitioner was consequently awarded the tender by the NCI on 15.02.2020, which it accepted on 19.03.2020.

Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 2 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29

4. About a year later, the respondent invited the petitioner for price negotiations in respect of its bid submitted on 15.11.2019. On 12.03.2021, the petitioner's representatives met with the Price Negotiation Committee of the respondent wherein they disclosed information regarding two contracts the petitioner had executed previously for supply of similar equipment to the Comprehensive Rural Health Services Project of AIIMS in Ballabgarh, in the year 2016 (hereinafter referred to as 'CRHP, Ballabgarh'), as well as the AIIMS Department of Emergency Medicine in 2015 (hereinafter referred to as the 'AIIMS Emergency'). On 27.03.2021, the respondent, after finding the petitioner's bid technically and commercially sound, issued a supply order in its favour, being S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/2020-21/St. The parameters of the contractual relationship between the parties was set out under this supply order, which contained an arbitration clause, and required the equipment to be delivered and installed on or before 31.03.2021. It is pertinent to note that the petitioner duly executed the supply order and effected delivery and installation of the equipment within time.

5. On 08.04.2021, the petitioner claims that, to its surprise, the Senior Stores Officer (Surgical Block) of the respondent issued a show cause notice to it, which reads as under:

"ALL INDIA INSTITUTE OF MEDICAL SCIENCES DEPARTMENT OF SURGICAL DISCIPLINES ANSARI NAGAR, NEW DELHI-110029 Email:storesection.newsurgicalblock@gmail.com (Surgical Block) MOST URGENT/TIME BOUND Dated: 08.04.2021 S.O. NO. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/2020-21/St. Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 3 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 To, M/S JOHNSON AND JOHNSON PVT. LTD.
PLOT NO. 118. P SECTOR-44 GURGAON 122 002 EMAIL: amishr24@its.jnj.com, vchopral@kn.ing.com Subject: Purchase of Combined Single Generator for Ultrasonic Cutting and Coagulation device with advance Radio-frequency energy (12 Nos.) -Show cause notice thereof.
Ref: 1. Tender No. 03/SB/M&E/2019-20/St,
2. Supply order No. S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/2020- 21/St. dated 27.03.2021.
Sir, Please refer to your quotation submitted against tender No. 03/SB/M&E/2019-20/St. and subsequent supply order No. S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/2020-21/St. dated 27.03.2021 for the purchase of Combined Single Generator for Ultrasonic Cutting and Coagulation device with advance Radio-frequency energy (12 Nos.) which has been supplied on 30.03.2021.
In this connection it has come to our notice that during the process of finalization of above tender and during process of reasonability of prices, you have concealed the rates of same quoted items (Equipment and Consumables) in NCI, Jhajjar quoted through some other distributor. The said tender was called by HLL wherein rates are lower than what quoted in above referred tender. Further it is also informed that the rates quoted for equipment alongwith consumables are lower than rates already approved in running rate contract with AIIMS vide No. 126/H/Suture Material. It has also come to the notice that M/s Johnson and Johnson Pvt. Ltd. has quoted lower rates to NCI Jhajjar through purchase done by HLL Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 4 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 even when there is running rate contract with AIIMS, Delhi. This unethical practice and concealment of facts have been viewed seriously by the competent authority and directed to issue show cause notice and explain the followings:
(a) Why the supply of equipment, accessories/consumables has been made at NCI, Jhajjar, Ballabgarh and Emergency Medicine at different rates?
(b) Why the copy of supply order issued by M/s HLL for same equipment at NCI, Jhajjar was not submitted to Store. Surgical Block while ascertaining reasonability of prices on the basis of like to like comparison of prices?
(c) Why you have quoted higher rates to Surgical Block for the same equipment and consumables as compared to NCI, Jhajjar?
(d) Why you have not informed the Store Officer, Main Hospital that you have lowered the rates of consumables/accessories at NCI, Jhajjar?

Your reply to this show cause notice must reach to the undersigned within 3 (three) days from the date of issue of this show cause notice but not later than 12.04.2021 upto 4.30 pm. In case, you failed to reply within stipulated date and time or satisfactory reply is not received, appropriate administrative action like cancellation of purchase order no. 08 Surgical Block/M&E/2020-21/St. dated 27.03.2021. debarring the firm for two years, recovery of excess amount paid so far in other running rate contracts and forfeiture of performance security shall be taken and no further correspondence in this regard, shall be entertained what so ever it may be.

It is issued with the approval of the competent authority. 

                            It may be accorded TOP PRIORITY."            (emphasis
                            supplied)

6. The petitioner sent its reply to the show cause notice on 15.04.2021 Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 5 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 and, while requesting for a personal hearing, also gave a detailed explanation for not disclosing details of the contracts that had been mentioned in the show cause notice. The relevant extract of the reply sent by the petitioner reads as under:

"15 April 2021 To, Sr. Stores Officer (Surgical Block), All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Department of Surgical Disciplines, Ansari Nagar, New Delhi - 110029 Subject: Show cause notice dated April 8, 2021 with S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/ 2020-21/St. in relation to Purchase of Combined Single Generator for Ultrasonic Cutting Radio- frequency energy (12 Nos.) Ref: 1. Tender No. 03/SB/M&E/ 2019-20/St.
2. Supply order No. S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/2020-21/St. dated 27.03.2021. Respected Sir/Madam, We, Johnson and Johnson Private Limited ("J&J" or "Company") are in receipt of the captioned show cause notice with ref: S.O. No. 08/Surgical Block/M&E/ 2020-21/St. dated April 8, 2021 ("Show Cause Notice"). We also refer to your email dated April 12, 2021, wherein we were permitted to submit response to this Show Cause Notice by April 15, 2021. In this regard, the Company is making the following submissions for your kind consideration and perusal.

                              A. Factual Background

                              *          *           *             *              *          *
7. We state that given that the five (5) tenders under consideration in the Show Cause Notice are separate and distinct and each has its pricing that is dependent on various Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 6 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 parameters that are unique to each tender, a comparison of pricing under the assumption that all tenders are alike in all respects would be incorrect. When we quote for tenders, we provide our quote on the basis of the tender requirements to ensure that the best possible price is offered to the customer. This is also stated in the price disclaimer that is submitted. It is also relevant to point out that Ballabgarh Tender and Emergency OT Tender were one-time orders and proprietary purchases, hence by no iota of imagination can a comparison with the AIIMS, SB Tender be drawn in isolation without considering the parameters and specific nuances of each of these tenders. Whilst there might be subtle similarities across identifiable parameters between NCI Tender, Ballabgarh Tender and Emergency OT Tender, the same were separate and distinct tenders too with no correlation and benchmarking to one another. The referenced tenders are separate and distinct from the AIIMS Tender. In view of this fact, you would appreciate that our Company has transparently disclosed "Disclaimer language" in the individual price bids for NCI Tender and AIIMS, SB Tender, respectively, highlighting the fact that the price quoted is the best price offered for the tendered quantities and price lower than the prices quoted may exist due to the terms of sale and other conditions applicable to such tenders.
The copies of price disclaimer letters dated October 12, 2018 and November 7, 2018, respectively filed with NCI Tender and AIIMS, SB Tender, respectively are annexed and marked herewith as Annexure I (Colly.).
8. We would further like to state that our Company had participated in the afore stated tenders through a process of competitive bidding, and upon due scrutiny and examination of our bids in line with the tender's technical and commercial requirements, the same were awarded to our Company by the Competent Authority after proper review and diligence.
9. With respect to tender 126/H/Suture Materials/2013-14 (126H tender"), we would like to state and submit that this tender was floated in 2014 for procurement of individual items Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 7 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 like sutures and other consumables including only one of the consumable items (HP054) that was included in NCI tender. This tender was awarded in 2015, and was valid only for two years, i.e., till 2017. The 126H tender did not contain any equipment or other consumables as contained in the NCI Jhajjar tender. It is also important to note that the 126H tender did not contain any minimum quantity commitment in the tender. Post expiry of the initial two years, the 126H tender was extended from time to time. The 126H tender being a tender for individual items without any minimum quantity commitment cannot be compared with the NCI Tender, which was a composite tender with detailed quantities of equipment, consumables and accessories to be provided in the tender.
10. It is germane to mention here that the terms of sale and pricing and technical specifications for every tender is exclusive to that tender and is premised on certain commercial, technical and management decisions prevailing at the relevant time. The Competent Authority has referred to five (5) tenders in their Show Cause Notice, having dissimilar- attributes and fulfilled between the years 2015 to 2021, hence no reasonable comparison can be made by the Competent Authority, whether in terms of price, terms of sale and/or other specifications after the successful grant and fulfillment of those tenders.
xxx" (emphasis supplied)
7. The petitioner's request for personal hearing was granted and the hearing was subsequently conducted on 20.04.2021 by a Committee constituted by the respondent. Pursuant to this hearing, the respondent, on 29.04.2021, passed the impugned order whereunder, the supply order dated 27.03.2021 was cancelled, the Earnest Money Deposit paid by the petitioner at the time of bid submission stood forfeited, and the petitioner was declared debarred from participating in any future tenders issued by the respondent for a period of two years from the date of passing of the impugned order. The Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 8 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 impugned order, passed on 29.04.2021, reads as under:
"i. The argument made by rep. of M/s Johnson & Johnson Pvt. Ltd. that all tenders are different and they can quote different rates in different tenders was not accepted by the Personal Hearing Committee as in the tender acceptance form, they have accepted all tender conditions under section-IX including fall clause undertaking at Serial No.33 of the TED.
ii. More importantly, firm informed the rates of supply order bearing no. 19/Emer. Med./M&E/PAC/2015-16 dated 30.12.2015 and supply order no.
145/BHC/Stores/2015-16 dated 22.02.2016 which were finalized during Financial Year 2015-16 but did not disclose the recent rates offered in NCI, Jhajjar vide Supply Order No. HITES/PCD/NCI-AIIMS/31/2019- 20/7179 dated 15.02.2020 for ascertaining the reasonability of prices in Surgical Block Tender. This has been considered to be unethical, misleading and unjustified on the part of the firm. The firm has deliberately misrepresented the facts to influence a procurement process within the meaning of fraudulent practice under the clause 48 of TED. Accordingly, AIIMS invoked TED 'Corrupt or Fraudulent Practices' clause at sr. No. 48 ofGIB against the firm."

(emphasis supplied)

8. Being aggrieved, the petitioner, vide its letters dated 01.05.2021, 10.05.2021, and 13.05.2021, approached the respondent seeking review and revocation of the impugned order primarily on the ground that no comparison could be made between the subject tender, i.e., the AIIMS, SB tender, and the tenders issued by the NCI, the CRHP, Ballabgarh and the AIIMS Emergency, as they were all unique and incomparable tenders with different terms and conditions of sale and involved orders with different quantities, combinations Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 9 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 and constructs. The petitioner's request for review was declined by the respondent who, vide the letter dated 21.05.2021, advised the petitioner to immediately take back the equipment provided by it against the supply order dated 27.03.2021. The petitioner, however, vide its letters dated 24.05.2021, 27.05.2021, and 31.05.2021, reiterated its request for review of the impugned order, but to no avail. It is in these circumstances that the present petition came to be filed before this Court on 17.06.2021.

9. On 29.07.2021, after learned senior counsel for the petitioner had concluded their submissions, learned Solicitor General appearing on behalf of the AIIMS had raised an objection regarding the maintainability of the petition by contending that the contractual relationship between the parties was governed by the supply order dated 27.03.2021, which contained an arbitration clause and had, therefore, contended that if aggrieved, the petitioner ought to seek arbitration in accordance with Clause 15 contained in Annexure 2 of the said supply order. He had urged that in view of the self- imposed judicial policy of limiting exercise of the extraordinary powers of the High Court under Article 226 of the Constitution, when an alternative and equally efficacious remedy is available with a litigant, it ought to be made to pursue the said remedy instead of being given a free reign to invoke the special jurisdiction of this Court. He also had urged that since the petitioner's termination had been duly effected as per the terms of the TED, and most of the issues raised by the petitioner were disputed and raised complex questions of facts pertaining to the terms and conditions of the AIIMS, SB tender - all of which required oral evidence, this Court, ought to decline the exercise of its writ jurisdiction and relegate the petitioner to arbitration in accordance with the terms of the contract.

10. In rebuttal, learned senior counsel for the petitioner submitted that an Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 10 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 arbitrator had very little power to deal with the issues raised in the present petition. The petitioner had been debarred, which, in effect, was an act of blacklisting; given that the consequences of blacklisting travelled far beyond the dealings with any one particular government entity and had real time consequences on the entire business of the petitioner company, even if termination of the contract could be assailed in arbitration, an order of blacklisting could not. It was then submitted that an arbitrator is, after all, a creature of the agreement and impugning an act of blacklisting was a public law action, not contractual; therefore, any order to blacklist an entity demanded public law remedies that could only be granted by a Court with writ jurisdiction. It was further submitted that the arbitrator, in any event, does not have any power to apply the test under Article 14 of the Constitution of India and other public law principles liable to be invoked in the facts of the present case, such as the doctrine of arbitrariness, for the purpose of setting aside a debarment order - only a Constitutional Court was empowered to do that. It was, therefore, submitted that arbitration could not be considered an equally efficacious remedy in any manner. It was finally urged, without prejudice to the aforesaid, that jurisdiction under Article 226 of the Constitution is neither excluded in the presence of an arbitration agreement, nor is the availability of an alternate remedy an absolute bar to writ jurisdiction. Subsequent to the response given by the petitioner, the learned Solicitor General did not really press the point of maintainability any further and, instead, chose to address his contentions on merits.

11. Before referring to the submissions made by the parties on merits, it may be noted that while this petition was being heard, the petitioner received communications from two medical institutions; two letters from the Sawai Man Singh Hospital at Jaipur, declaring the bids made by the petitioner Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 11 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 through its distributors under NIB No. 1350 dated 28.04.2021 non-responsive on account of the impugned order, and one letter from King George's Medical University at Lucknow on 29.07.2021, where the petitioner currently stands engaged in a contract, seeking clarifications in respect of its continued engagement. These letters were placed on record by the petitioner in support of its plea that the impugned order not only affects its business relationship with the respondent, but also has a cascading effect on its business relationship with other medical institutions.

12. Learned senior counsel Mr. Mukul Rohatgi and Mr. Saurabh Kirpal, advanced submissions on behalf of the petitioner. It was submitted that the petitioner, being a global healthcare and medical technology company present in over 65 countries, as a brand enjoys tremendous goodwill in the market and is a well-regarded name in the industry. For this reason, the petitioner has always ensured that its actions do not offend any national laws or regulations and the petitioner, even in the present case, has not indulged in any unethical practices or concealment of material facts in respect of the tender in question. It was contended that, for starters, the impugned order is premised on a wholly erroneous interpretation of the 'Fall Clause' provision and other terms and conditions of the TED. It was submitted that the terms and conditions of the TED did not at all make it incumbent on the bidder to either provide the lowest prices to the respondent, or disclose the rates offered in all recently executed contracts for ascertaining the reasonability of prices quoted by the bidder. It was urged that the contractual provision that required bidders to disclose rates in recently executed contracts could be invoked only in case of tenders with identical terms and conditions, which is clearly not the case here. Given that the 'Fall Clause' could only come into effect after the petitioner and the respondent had executed the contract between themselves, there was Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 12 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 no question of the petitioner disclosing details of the contract with the NCI which was executed much earlier. It was submitted that the petitioner earned a major part of its revenue from the number of consumables ordered, which differed in the case of the orders placed by the NCI and AIIMS, SB, therefore they were substantially different and could not be compared. The petitioner had, in fact, made this position very clear when it sent a price disclaimer to the respondent on 07.11.2019, prior to submitting its bid, stating that it may have quoted lower prices for the equipment earlier, depending on the terms of sale and other conditions applicable during the pendency of such other contract. It was urged that even otherwise when the petitioner had submitted its bid on 15.11.2019, there was admittedly no concluded contract with the NCI at that point and, therefore, the petitioner could not be expected to furnish details of its contract which it entered into with the NCI only on 19.03.2020, in its bid submitted much prior thereto, i.e., on 15.11.2019. It was, thus, contended that there was no question of the petitioner having deliberately concealed any information from the respondent and indulging in any corrupt or fraudulent practice under Clause 48 of the TED. Further, by placing reliance on the decisions in Mekaster Trading Corporation Vs. Union of India &Ors. 2003 (71) DRJ 376 and Rama Pandey Vs. Union of India & Anr. ILR (2009) 6 Del 752, Mr.Rohatgi urged that even otherwise, the impugned order was wholly cryptic and does not deal with the primary defense of the petitioner that when the quantity of consumables and accessories ordered by the NCI and AIIMS, SB were very different, the contracts with each of them could not be called identical at all. Finally, it was contended that the 'Fall Clause' provision, which the respondent has invoked in the impugned order, is wholly inapplicable to the facts of the present case, as the said clause has a very limited purpose of vesting the respondent with Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 13 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 the option of seeking a price reduction- which was not the case here as the petitioner did not receive any request from the respondent for reducing the price of the goods being supplied under the subject contract. Moreover, it was specifically reiterated that the 'Fall Clause' could be invoked to seek a price reduction only upon a comparison with identical contracts having the same terms and conditions which, it was urged, was not the position in the present case.

13. It was then submitted that the impugned order was arbitrary, discriminatory and completely disproportionate to the violations alleged to have been committed by the petitioner. The respondent could not have arbitrarily resorted to the extreme and harsh step of debarring the petitioner as a punishment in the ordinary course of business, considering that the act of debarment was, in effect, an act of blacklisting - which has serious consequences. It was submitted that the cancellation of the contract awarded in the petitioner's favour had caused it significant financial losses and damaged its reputation, which was only likely to increase in the aftermath of the blacklisting. In this regard, reliance was placed on the decision of the Supreme Court in Kulja Industries Limited Vs. Chief Gen. Manager (2014) 14 SCC 731 to contend that the decision of the respondent to blacklist the petitioner had to withstand the test of fairness, natural justice, relevance, non- discrimination, quality and proportionality. Yet, the entire premise of the impugned order was an erroneous assumption that the petitioner, while submitting its bid to the respondent in November 2019, had malafidely chosen to not inform the respondent about the price quoted by it for the equipment ordered by the NCI, without considering the admitted position that the contract with the NCI was executed only in March 2020. It was ultimately urged that, given the petitioner's reliable brand name in the field of supplying Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 14 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 medical devices for decades, its past record of having satisfactorily serviced the respondent under previous contracts with no complaint of any wrongdoing, and its inability to reveal details of a contract which did not exist in November 2019, the decision to blacklist the petitioner was clearly disproportionate and unwarranted. It was prayed that the impugned order be quashed and set aside for the aforesaid reasons.

14. Per contra, learned Solicitor General submitted that the decision to blacklist the petitioner arose after a careful deliberation upon the facts of this case. It was submitted that at the time of personal hearing before the respondent's Committee, the petitioner did not plead that the terms and conditions of the contracts executed between the NCI and the petitioner on the one hand, and the petitioner and the respondent on the other hand, were incomparable. It was further submitted that the respondent, after executing the supply order in favour of the petitioner on 27.03.2021, later found out that the petitioner had participated in the tender process with unclean hands since it had failed to disclose material information regarding its previous business arrangement with other hospitals in respect of the very same equipment. The terms and conditions of the TED showed that the respondent wanted all bidders to ensure the highest standards of ethics at the stage of procurement of the order and its execution and to that end, required certain disclosures from them at the time of bid submission. For instance, the Qualification Criteria in Section VIII of the TED made it incumbent on all bidders to meticulously disclose the names of the firms and details of orders specified in Proforma 'A', titled Proforma for Performance Statement, wherein similar equipment meeting major parameters of technical specification had been supplied and installed in the last five years. Given that the TED sought supply of Combined Single Generators for Ultrasonic Cutting and Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 15 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 Coagulation device with advance Radio-Frequency Energy, the petitioner was required to submit a disclosure as per the format in Proforma 'A', which contained details of other orders for supply of the same equipment, that had been executed in the five preceding years. Ideally, the petitioner ought to have provided details of more recent orders that had been placed for the same equipment, such as the ones executed with the NCI in 2020 and CRHP, Ballabgarh in 2018 while submitting its bid. Instead, the petitioner filled the disclosure form with details of an order that was placed as far back as in 2012

- that quoted relatively higher prices for the equipment. It was contended that even if the petitioner's plea that it could not disclose the prices quoted to the NCI in November 2019 at the time of bid submission since the contract with the NCI had not been executed by then were to be believed, there is still no explanation as to why the petitioner did not disclose the same at the time of appearing for price negotiations before the respondent's Price Negotiation Committee in March 2021, even though the contract with the NCI had been admittedly executed in March 2020 itself. The fact that the possibility of such a disclosure had not been conceived by the petitioner cannot be believed since it was at the time of price negotiations that it had furnished to the respondent other contracts that it had executed with the CRHP, Ballabgarh and AIIMS Emergency in respect of the equipment. It was submitted that the intent behind seeking such mandatory disclosures of past price quotations was to ensure that the respondent could purchase the equipment at the best market price, which meant that the respondent did not have a free hand to pick and choose which of its recently concluded project ought to be disclosed to the respondent. Notwithstanding the aforesaid, the petitioner, while submitting its bid on 15.11.2019 and participating in price negotiations in March 2021 prior to finalizing the Supply Order, had willfully failed to Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 16 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 disclose to the respondent details of its ongoing contracts with the NCI executed on 19.03.2020. It was urged that this omission was a calculated decision on the part of the petitioner to withhold from the respondent that it had quoted lesser prices for the equipment in previous, more recently executed contracts. It was further urged that, by committing such an omission, the petitioner was guilty of 'fraudulent practices' under Clause 48.1(a)(ii) contained in Section II of the TED to influence the procurement process or contract execution, to the detriment of the respondent by charging it much higher prices for the same equipment. It was submitted, by delving into the purpose of the 'Fall Clause' provision and emphasizing upon the use of the term 'identical product' therein, that the 'Fall Clause' is a price safety mechanism which provides that, if the contract holder reduces its price or is selling identical goods at a lower price to any person or organization during currency of the contract with the respondent, the contract price would be automatically reduced with effect from that date for all the subsequent supplies under the contract and the contract in question shall stand amended accordingly. It was contended that there was absolutely no merit in the petitioner's contention that the 'Fall Clause' would have come into play only after execution of the contracts dated 27.03.2021 as the said provision was fully applicable to any sale during the currency of the respondent's supply order, which was valid for a period of one year and, thus, brought existing contractual arrangements with CRHP, Ballabgarh and the NCI, very much within the purview of the 'Fall Clause' provision. It was urged that by adopting such hyper-technical interpretation of the 'Fall Clause' provision, the petitioner was attempting to deflect any questions on the obvious omissions and misrepresentations it had indulged in, in order to mislead the respondent into executing the supply order. It was submitted that in this Signature Not Verified Signed By:GARIMA MADAN Location: W.P.(C) 5989/2021 Page 17 of 46 Signing Date:26.08.2021 13:34:29 manner, the petitioner was found guilty of violating crucial provisions of the TED.

15. It was then submitted that the impugned order, a speaking order, has been passed by the respondent by duly following the principles of fairness, non-discrimination, and natural justice since the petitioner had been served with a show cause notice, given time to file its reply thereto and provided with ample opportunities to present its case. 41. As observed by the Supreme Court in Erusian Equipment & Chemicals Ltd. (supra), an order of blacklisting casts a slur on the party being blacklisted and is stigmatic. Given the nature of such an order and the import thereof, it would be unreasonable and arbitrary to visit every contractor who is in breach of his contractual obligations with such consequences.

In Sarku Engineering Services (supra), a Division Bench of the Bombay High Court considered the case of a contractor (the petitioner therein) who had been blacklisted on the allegation that it was responsible for major delay in execution of a contract entered into with Oil and Natural Gas Corporation Limited (respondent no. 2 therein).
